comments.text: Good spot, covered by an overpass and next to a grocery store.
Good spot for heading towards Sendai. There's a traffic light, the cars go fairly slowly because they have to turn and there should be plenty of space to stop. Also easily accessible I think
The first car stopped. Guy wasn't even going to Imabari but decided to take us.

There's a gas station but just past it there's 2 cafes on opposite sides, useful for if you're going north or south. I used the cafe cause the traffic was much more one direction and not muddled in the intersection.
Not a long wait.
Should be at the junction of the 292 and the 342
Not the most comfortable place to stand, but there is plenty of traffic,and enough space by the side of the road for cars to stop.

There is a good number of people climbing the mountain (especially on weekends) and it's fairly easy to hitch back from the parking area near the temple back to Aso town. People will know you are a traveller without a car who just came here to climb the mountain, so they won't have any worries. A tip for climbing: follow the path going left and climb the rocky route to the top first (it is well marked with yellow arrows), make a circle clockwise and make your way down by following the paved rout
Near by there is a bus stop where car can safely stop. I waited only 10 minutes. (going in direction of Koga)

Big SA near Onomichi and Fukuyama with access from Bingo-Akasaka station (3km walk). Is open to the outside, so no sneaking-in required. Has an excellent spot just outside a dog run where you can hitch from.

å®‰é”å¤ªè‰¯SA
It looks smaller on this map than it actually is (it's a big, main SA that covers both sides of the expressway). It's a three kilometer walk from Motomiya Station, so good access to/from Koriyama. Nice view of Mt. Bandai too.

Service area very close to the train station (Kaida). You can just walk around to the gate and walk straight in. Useful for escaping from Sendai (980 yen), and presumably a good way out of Fukushima too.
Hasuda SA. Easy access from the Utsunomiya line. Need to jump the fence, but it's low and there are some convenient bushes to hide you.

We were walking towards the roadside station when we found this spot (a bus station). Nice visibility, easy for cars to stop, at the end of town so you can easily get a ride to Hamada.
A nice lady living in Masuda took us all the way to a roadside station near Masuda.
first time hitchhiking ever, got a ride real quick in a toyota 86 gt. there was another hitchhiker trying to get to yamaguchi but i got a ride before him as he went to the toilet.

Was recommended to hitchhike from out the front of the shopping centre by locals. If you stand on the hill people can see you from the traffic lights and pull into the shopping centre carpark to pick you up. Got a lift all the way back to Tokyo after waiting about an hour
Amikoj iris al Totori sed lasis min tie. Tia benzinostacio estas granda kaj bona.
Mirinda loko. 2 homoj dum nokto kun multaj dorsosakon plus Daniela gxis baajis house.
See hitchwiki; best spot to go out of Fukuoka. Waited 5 minutes at the end with a sign for Kumamoto, and got a car dropping me there. Easily reachable by tram.
There's a lawson just at the entrance of the highway. Many people going both ways stop there. Had a guy pick me up after buying a few things. (A sign is required)
Girl hitchhiking alone, two lovely women took me to Lake Otsu, they were going straight to Kyoto. Many people passing that station.

Took the train from Matsumoto station up to Shinshimashima (about where people take the bus to Kamikochi). Try there or around the 7-Eleven that has parking on both sides of the road. 
PS: We took the mountain pass towards Takayama instead of the normal way, very pretty!
Hitched two times, one to Shizuoka and one straight to Nagoya. Really accommodating and really interested about your traveling
Awesome spot on a convenience store right before the IC booth, so you only get cars going on the national highway. My destination was Sendai and the driver was heading to Matsushima.
lots of traffic, but going both ways. A little difficult to get to
Lots of cars, picked up me and another hitchhiker

I was walking with a sign saying Yufu with Japanese characters heading to Road 11. A Japanese man walking his dog stopped me and explained that my sign said the name of the city I was already in. Woops! He asked me where I was going and after I explained it to him, he offered to give me ride there as it was on his way home. Before the ride he gave me a meal as his cafe with his family and brought me to an onsen. Fantastic experience!

Good spot to get a ride to Mt Aso crater after taking the bus.
Only thumb, no sign.

I didn't have to wait, someone saw me walking with my sign and asked me where I wanted to go.
From Nobeoka my goal was Fukuoka but I went step by step and I just told him Kurume.
He took me, and told me he took many hichhikers on that road.
I don't exactly where you wanna stand on that place, but it's a big roadway station so you should be fine. Just don't be afraid to go step by step.

All the cars that goes to the roadway station will pass next to you, and when they'll go back to the road they will pass next to you again.
I don't like to stand on the roadway station itself but it might be better, anyway you can decide when you're there, it's really easy to move here :)
I wrote "Hajimemashite :) Kumamoto direction" in Japanese in my sign.
Always have my arm straight and my thumb up.
Although there was little space for vehicles to stop, the wait was not too long.
I waited for 30 minutes at the traffic lights at the gas station. A Japanese guesthouse owner picked me up in his car and put me up for a night at his house. Hitchhiking was easy here.
Many people pass through this road as it connects to the free highway in the future. I had a very comfortable journey to Shirahige Tori
Write your destination on a piece of paper and there will definitely be a stop. You don't have to wait long as it is a famous road. Don't forget to buy supplies from 7-Eleven.

Right after the toll there is a place to pullover. The toll halts the traffic, and the visibility is OK. Sign saying Tokyo. Ride in 7 minutes with a really cool dude who took me all the way to central Tokyo. He even spoke a little english! There is a bus from the theme park to Tokyo, it's 2200 Yen or somthing if this fails.

Sign to GOJO. Decent pull in area eastbound, also traffic is slowed by traffic lights so is often stopped next to you looking terrified. Good visibility. Driver spoke almost no english but Google translate ftw. Ride direct to gojo.

At sunset, just after the bridge is a small pull in kind of thing, a kind person stopped. They where going to the other side of town but unsolicited drove further down the road to a good camp spot. Spoke a little english, fun Google translate conversation. Had sign for the coast.

At the end of the bridge in the middle of town there is a small layby (not a bus stop), the traffic is slow and visibility is OK. 50 minute wait. Not amazing but not terrible, a lot of traffic passed and it was local, i also feel like my sign for a tourist destination far away repelled short distance rides. Driver stops and is going to Shingu! He speaks very very
Little english but is a kind legend and we have a fun Google translate conversation. The locals where quite fun, some thought I was f

You can walk up here and set up on the pavement honestly. There's a space where cars can pull over, and luckily for me, the first car pulled over going straight to where I need to go. It's only useful if you're going north/east out of Kochi.
Gas station, plenty of space to pull over. All traffic is going North, or south depending on your desired direction. But very easy to get a ride

This is a very open place to HH. The traffic isn't crazy through here, but as it's one-directional to the east, getting a ride is fairly straightforward. 
I luckily got a ride straight to yamaguchi, but people also use this to go to Sanyoonoda and Ube.
Gas station and a adjoining road to the highway. A couple pulled over after 10 mins and took me a long way north. Almost all traffic is going towards Kitakyushu.

Great service area to get dropped off with lots of traffic.We spend the night there because it got late and there were multiple warm areas that are open 24 hours were we could sleep. Showers and laundry are also available. The next morning we immediately got picked up when somebody saw our sign :)
lovely SA for drivers before leaving kyushu, good visibility and opps to chat with drivers before they leave the SA. multiple drivers stopped but held out for direct ride which came!
First car stopped!

Around 9:30 am. I think around 5 cars passed along the road, and about the fifth one coming from 7-11 stopped and gave me a ride. I was seconds away from writing the first stroke of åŒ— on my empty sign. Other places in Oki awa hundreds and hundreds of cars passed without stopping.
Solo Caucasian Woman. Second car picked me up. Had a sign for nagoya in kanji

Solo Caucasian Woman with a sign in Kanji for GIFU and an umbrella because it was raining. Hit the hitchhhiking rainbow and got a driver going all the way past my final destination so I went the whole way!!
Only waited 5 minutes at the petrol station before at truck driver came to me to drive me to the next rest area. You cang get there if you want to go to Kurume or Fukuoka
Solo white woman. Had a sign for Takachiho as I planned to stop there omw to Oita. The driver who picked me up was stopping there and going to Aso so I went all the way to this point with him
Solo white woman with a Kanji sign for Takachiho

Solo white woman travelling with a big backpack. Trying to get to Takachiho today - unfortunately not many service areas close to the turn of for Takachiho coming from Miyazaki. I had a sign for Nebeoka in Kanji

Solo Caucasian Woman. Took the train from Kurashiki to shinkurashiki and walked 4km to this highway service area. It took about 1h to walk and I had to jump a small fence because the road takes you to behind the shops at the road side not the front.

Ride took me all the way to hiroshima which was my final destination.
Solo Caucasian Woman travelling with a sign for Okayama. Family knew english and knew the word hitchhiking. Waited at exit ramp to highway with thumb, sign and smile
Got dropped here by previous ride. Going north to Takashima/Makino. Got a ride really fast.

Yes you have to climb a fence but it was doable :D at the side of the hospital there was a bush that was hiding us well from the street, t helps if you are 2 people though so you can lift eachother over the fence. At the service area you can easily cross to the other side. We met a Japanese hitchhiking couple here that told us they climb over the gate regularly. We got a ride for all 4 of us after around 20 minutes of asking. Perfect spot to leave osaka:)

Yooo the other guy was right, I had to jump a fuc*in fence lol. I did that on the southern side with the park/garden whatever since nobody will see you. But be careful cause there are some highway cameras after you jump, I'd say stick close to the side of the road and move fast. I went straight to the bathroom for some 10 mins just in case, then the hitchhiking went pretty smoothly, big time traffic. I was going to Tokushima, some guy going to southern Kyushu picked me up all the way. 
Easy spo

I went here again. This time the gate was closed and pretty solidly locked.
If you go over to the other side of the highway and walk up the side there's another gate that's much more private (the other one is outside a hospital) you can jump over. Alternatively, further down the other side there's some weird garden feature that connects directly to the parking area but is surrounded with lots of trees and bushes - presumably you could jump the fence there easier, though it's further to walk to.

Service area close to Kishibe station on the Kyoto line. There's a gate on the station side that you can open and walk in, and a bridge connects both sides of the service area. Plenty of traffic. Perfect to escape from Osaka.
Caucasian Woman travelling alone. First car picked me up. Had a sign for Sumoto in Kanji. Waited by ramp to highway around 5pm still daylight

æˆ‘æ˜¯åŽ»çŽ©ä¸¥å²›ç¥žç¤¾ï¼Œå†åŽ»è¿™ä¸ªSAçš„ã€‚åŽ»è¿™é‡Œçš„è·¯ä¸Šä¼šç»è¿‡ä¸€æ¡å±±è·¯ã€‚ä¸ç”¨ç´§å¼ ã€‚è·¯ä¸Šçš„æ ‘å¶ä¼šæ¯”è¾ƒå¤šã€‚ä¼šç»åŽ†ä¸€æ®µçˆ¬å¡ã€‚æ‚¨å¯èƒ½ä¼šæ¯”è¾ƒç´¯ã€‚æˆ‘èµ°äº†ä¸¤æ¬¡å¼¯è·¯ï¼Œæˆ‘æ‰åˆ°é‚£é‡Œçš„ã€‚è°·æ­Œåœ°å›¾æˆ‘ä»¥ä¸ºå®ƒåäº†ã€‚ä½†ä»–æ²¡æœ‰ï¼Œå› ä¸ºä»–å¯¼èˆªçš„éƒ½æ˜¯ä¸€äº›å°è·¯ï¼Œå±±è·¯ã€‚ä½ åªè¦è·Ÿç€è°·æ­Œåœ°å›¾èµ°ï¼Œå°±èƒ½åˆ°è¿™ä¸ªåœ°æ–¹ã€‚è¿‡ç¨‹ä¼šæ¯”è¾ƒè‰°è¾›ã€‚æˆ‘åªèŠ±äº†20~30åˆ†é’Ÿæ‰“åˆ°è½¦ã€‚æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ª70å²å·¦å³çš„å–„è‰¯è€äººã€‚æˆ‘å¾ˆæƒ³äº«å—å’Œä»–åœ¨è½¦ä¸ŠèŠå¤©çš„æ—¶å…‰ã€‚å¸Œæœ›åŽæ¥çš„æ‰€æœ‰æ­ä¾¿è½¦çš„äººéƒ½èƒ½æ‰“åˆ°è½¦ï¼ŒåŽ»ä½ æƒ³è¦çš„åœ°æ–¹ã€‚

So I was going down do Kyushu, idk how the other people got to this station, maybe they got dropped off there, but I had to pass a trail full of spiders and webs and then jump a fence to enter ðŸ’€ the fence is rather easy to jump but you need a stick to clear all the spiders, kinda felt like some Indiana Jones type of shit, so be prepared. Unless youâ€™re doing it on 8th of September 2024 then I cleared all the creatures on that trail. 
Speaking of the spot itself, I was holding a Fukuoka sign, Ca

Lots of cars were going north. I had a sign just for Kyushu. Got a,lift after 20 mins. Bit of a pain getting to this service area from hiroshima right now because there were road works so it was about a 1h walk from the tram.

At first I was worried that the spot was gonna be bad because it really doesn't seem like cars could stop anywhere. BUT: after only 2 minutes I got a ride to himeji with a very kind family.
They stopped their car in a road parallel to the onramp, so if you attract cars from the main road, they will have a chance to stop there and reenter onto the highway, so don't worry.
I even got help from the local firefighters at their building just down the road, one of them walked me all the way to the p
By first sight it really seems a bad spot, as it is described above. However, it worked out quiet well. I just had to wait for 20 mins. This spot works for both directions.

Might seem like a poor spot because there is little place for cars to stop, but I did manage to find a ride here. Plus, it's very easy to access from central Kobe. This road leads right up to the Hanshin expressway, both directions.
Great for leaving Tokyo to Kofu, I was going to the Minami Alps via the Kofu Station bus the next day.
As said on the Wiki, quite easy to get in. Just go up the ramp to the bike parking area and go through the gate. Very busy on Saturday noon.
Perfect place to go to Lake Kawaguchiko! You can reach this parking area that is on the highway already by foot!! I walked from Hino station, not that far but a bit of a hill climbing.
Small but with plenty of traffic. Walking distance from Hino and Toyoda stations.
Solo Caucasian Woman with a sign for Okayama in Kanji. Waited by exit ramp. Super easy

Was here by accident - caught the wrong train, and while waiting the hour for the next one saw this on the map and thought why not.
Would be good for if you were leaving Shikoku, I guess.

Service area near the station. ~660 yen from Takamatsu.
Going towards Takamatsu is fairly small but still sufficient traffic to get picked up. Other side looks significantly bigger.
Big service area and easy to enter. Sadly not much traffic going beyond Nagoya to Osaka on a Monday.
Once I arrived at the service station, I expected long waiting time due to the size of the parking slots and the amount of cars. However, I worked out quiet well.

Short walk from Kurozasa station. Not a huge parking area but good enough. 630 yen from Nagoya station. Note that the first hill you come across isn't where the parking area is - go around until you get to the expressway and walk up. There's a big farm tourist attraction thingy that you walk by, and there are signs inviting you to walk into the PA.
Pretty good spot. You have a chance to be picked up either by the cars passing by or those leaving the gas station/convenience store. Walking from Beppu is possible though it takes long.
There were plenty of cars, I got a ride going north to Honshu.
Seven-Eleven parking lot, 15 minutes walking from Bungotoyooka station (Â¥230 by train from Beppu).
There is a toilet, lots of space. A truck driver took us even thou we were a couple, he suggested me to hide behind curtain in his cabin, my partner was sitting in the front.

West towards Takamatsu. Not much traffic when I was there around 1pm. But the spot is good and lots of space to pull over near the bus stop. Easy access from Bandou train station. A gate but unlocked + legal. (No "do not enter" signs like some others)
A quiet road running north first before curving southeast towards Hachinohe, Morioka. There is enough traffic here to get a ride quite quickly, though.

As both Zushi and Kamakura are touristy places, this spot has many tourists passing through. Some of them possibly going a longer distance. This road eventually merges with national road #1, going all the way to Kyoto.

Service area from where you can hitch a ride to Tokyo quite easily. You can go in and out freely - if you walk down into the valley, there is a bus terminal right underneath the highway. From here busses run to Shizuoka station. If you want to get here from Shizuoka station, then take bus #1391 to Yatsu terminal (è°·æ´¥ã‚¿ãƒ¼ãƒŸãƒŠãƒ«).
Easy spot. Many cars. You won't have to wait long here.
Easy spot for getting on the Joban expressway. Too bad it's so far out of Tokyo. You can go to Shinmoriya station by train and walk from there.
Good spot for hitching to the Kyoto or Kobe direction. Plenty of room for cars to stop.

Actually it's a pretty good spot. Just before the toll gate and there is a small space where cars can pull over. However, I've always had difficulty hitching at interchanges and here it also took me more than an hour to stop a car. But you can walk here from the center of Hiroshima, which is good.

There is a service area somewhere around here (I think it was called Ishiyama). It is a nice spot and even if you are travelling from Nagasaki to Kumamoto (or vice versa) it's better if you go here. There is also an underpass and you can cross to the other side of the highway (the other service area).
Plenty of traffic but it took some time before finding a ride to Tokyo.
There is a junction just after this Seven-Eleven parking lot which means that part of the traffic is not going to the express way.
I waited 40 minutes before having a lift to Himeji.
This gas stations is a good spot just before the express way with plenty of traffic. You can either go east to Tokyo or west to Okayama / Hiroshima.

Large service area. It's a bit too far from the train stations, but if you're trying to leave Matsumoto or somewhere else nearby it still might be more worthwhile taking the train here then walking than waiting at the interchange.
There's also an onsen in the service area, should you be in desperate need of a bath.

The first really viable hitchhiking spot along this road going towards Takayama. There's a small parking area in between two sets of traffic lights with just enough room at the end of the parking lot for someone from the road to pull over. It's not great, but it's something.

Wait in front of the toll stations. Cars slow down and can stop on the hard shoulders. Have a sign in Japanese letters with you to make sure people understand what you are doing and what you want from them.

so this is an OK place, as there are 2 places for cars to stop: one quiet parking lot right of the station, and some space if you walk down towards the ENEOS gas station. but there's too much local traffic and we were going to Nagato then Hagi, but this coastal road 191 isn't the fastest route. Need to wait a bit.
good place but was somehow unlucky. recommend standing in front of 7-11 and directly asking

Ni kampadis apud Lawson-vendejo, sed bedaÅ­rinde ni ne zorgis pri organizi nin anticipe por preni la trajnon. Do ni demandis ulon, kiu estis parkita en Lawson-aÅ­to, kaj tio estis Serg, afabla ukraino, kiu loÄas en Japanio de 20 jaroj, kaj ni petis lin veturigi nin nur al la fervoja stacio, sed li veturigis nin al la flughaveno. Ni iris al Filipinoj post preskaux 3 minotaj en Japanio.
Tre bona loko por enira Osaka aux eliri la flughaveno.

La lasta veturo en la lasta tago de petveturado de Istanbulo al Soja, direktiÄante al la Äˆielarka Internacia Kunveno de 2025. Daniela kaj mi. Finfine. Mi dormis tute proksime en arbetaro apud la enirado de tia vojo.
Ni domandi tie Äis la Onson
Nagoya->Osaka pt2. Got dropped off here, short ride to Osaka.
Nagoya->Osaka pt1. Fair amount of traffic, the fences to get inside the SA are always open. Got picked up by a nice trucker!
only relevant when there are a lot of visitors to the temple (holidays, weekends, etc). I stood near the bathroom so everyone taking a break saw me

Not many cars passing through the area from 6:00-9:00am, though many people approached me for fukuoka, so may be a good place to stop if youâ€™re heading to fukuoka. I went to kagoshima-chuo after being dropped off at minamata station; nice driver bought me the ticket!

Since this is a road that goes around town, I thought it would be good to hitchhike but there was no place where cars would hear. After you pass under the train tracks, there are more stopping places for cars on the road and there is also a FamilyMart.
Although there was little space for vehicles to stop, the wait was not too long.
Thereâ€™s a sidewalk by the on ramp for the toll booths. Cars stopping at the light and turning left have plenty of time to read your sign. I think itâ€™s the quickest way out of Aomori.

Right before the tunnel that leads directly to Fukuoka, a little hard for the drivers to spot you however there is designated parking by the Lawson's store and they have ample time to spot you because of the traffic lights. Optimal for quickly leaving Nagasaki without the need for an SA.
Decetn spot to go nort on the island. Doubt this is any good to go to Okayama. Got me to Takamatsu. The traffic slow-ish so theres enough time to pull into the car park.

Good spot but not a large amount of people actually stopped here. Though, great as if someone does, they,re definitely going east. This is no good for going west.
To get into here by foot, you'll have to jump the fence, or if you're lucky like me, the backdoor was open :)

People were hesitant to pick me up, late afternoon-ish. Traffic turning onto the motorway don't have time to react, but you'll get a ride within an hour. 
A nice man couldn't take me, but stopped to give me an umbrella as it was raining.

visible spot for passing traffic, not ideal for stopping however. luckily kind trucker stopped along same road and picked up me+1 holding kumamoto sign+thumb; ended up going with him all the way to oita tho!
7 eleven parking lot before entrance to urban highway. Fukuoka direction, got a ride for Koga SA from there directly. 40min walk from the station, bus or monorail also possible

Parking Area is easily accessible. I used the one towards north/east (Matsumoto), so Iâ€™m not sure about the other side. 
It has vending machines and a shop with food but no Konbini.
I asked a truck driver to take me. Was there at 6am in the morning, so not much traffic. But it seems decently sized, so I guess you will get your ride if you are patient. Itâ€™s a 12 minutes walk from Magome-Juku

Tricky spot because of the cars exiting the PA going across the main road to the highway. Got a ride from someone walking up to me, not sure if a car would have ever pulled over while driving out. Going to Okayama across Seto bridge

I went to the 7eleven bought a pen to write my sign and then got picked up by a nice guy after nearly 10 min. He took me to Takasaki city and dropped me off at a supermarket where I could walk up easily to a road headed towards the highway. The 7eleven was on road 291 and the speed limit was around 50km/hour or 70km/hour but people drove slow enough to read and react to the sign. It was on a Sunday maybe it won't matter to you but I have a better track of getting rides on a Sunday.

Big service area with good infrastructure. I used it to get to Nagoya. Quite a big distance on foot from the nearest station but once you are there it's easily accessible from the north side, where you find stairs that lead to the small park of the service area. Traffic wasn't that much but decent enough to get picked up quite fast. At least on Tuesday afternoon.

A good spot to get from the Fuji area backt to the expressway at the coast. Easily accessible with the blue sightseeing bus from Kawaguchiko and a 10 min walk. You can stand behind a road barrier with good visibility and a small road behind for cars to pull in. Also decent traffic on a Tuesday morning.

Walked form the nearest station in theory it's not a bad place to hitch out from headed west, I flew a sign until a bus driver with an empty bus smoki g a cigarette asked me if hamamatsu would be good enough , and I ended up there where granted I couldnt get a ride before sundown , but still it resulted in a nice week of beach bumming before I went back to tokyo. There is a cart with cardboard behind the convenience store you can use to make a sign. For best results stand on the manhole cover to

The spot was very good. It can be accessed very easily through a passage behind the convenience store and you won't be walking where cars drive.
The station has everything, toilets, wifi, electrical plugs for charging your devices, Food etc.
I got picked up after one hour waiting time on a Monday. I started at 10am and got a lift at 11am.
It took me a total of 4 rides to get to Nagoya station and the drivers were always very respectful and curious why I'm hitchhiking in japan.
Tomorrow I'll

The spot is really good. Lot's of cars, many people go to toilet or getting a snack. I got a ride after 45 mins. However, I was waiting in front of the exit. I experience it works out better waiting in front of the entrance of the convenient stores / food hall.
I got a ride in about 20 minutes to Shizuoka. Great spot.
Within 10 minutes, someone walked up to us and offered to take us all the way to Kyoto. It's a big place - don't go there too late though, or you'll mostly find cars with sarary men taking a nap.
Okay, have now tried it going east, and it was easy. So for leaving Kyoto heading east, good spot - otherwise, avoid/

Going east might be different, but if you're going west there's really no good place to stand or for cars to stop. There's decent traffic, so it's doable, but I wouldn't recommend it if you can help it. Make sure you have a map with the next SA you want to get to with you that you can just point at, because the expressway branches crazily soon after this.
Big service area with access from Otsu station and thus Kyoto. Has a nice view of Lake Biwa.
Lots of cars but access is tricky. The gate from the underpass path has a do not enter sign and there are people around so it could be frowned on.
Small parking area. There is a gate blocking off the entrance but I was unlocked.

it's a fairly small PA - there's a direct bus to it from Takayama (run by JR and departs from the central station) for about 500 yen... getting there is a little tricky if you have openmaps/maps.me because it shows a bridge before the PA which I was intending on using but a local told me there's no access to the PA from there - use google maps because it shows a tiny access road that will lead you all the way to the PA

About three kilometers from the nearest station, so fairly easy way to escape from Kanazawa. There's a bus too, if you don't feel like walking. It's not a huge parking area, but there's enough traffic that you'll inevitably be picked up
This is the edge of town so walking further is pointless. You don't actually have to walk this far out to be able to get a ride, probably. If you're lucky you can find rides all the way to Asahikawa.
You can wait near the parking place of the BMW shop. Drivers can stop there. Good way to get on the Meishin expressway (leading to Nagoya, Kyoto).

It's not a good spot. It's the beginning of the tunnel to the expressway and the cars going there drive on the right lane, making it almost impossible to stop for you or even see you. I waited 3 hours before an English speaking helpful guy drove back just to take me. I would try to find another spot that connects to the expressway.

I waited for 40min at 9h in the morning on a Sunday. Then got ride to Fukuoka (I was heading Osaka).
I asked the driver to stop in a car park on the highway. Although is prohibitted is the best place to get a ride. I rode to Osaka from Nagasaki with 4 different cars, wating an average of 20 min from car to car. Hitchhiking in Japan is great!!
Most people here won't even look at you, basically. There probably isn't a better spot in the area though.
I can't find the exact place on this map, but it's around here. It's a rest station with an omiyage shop and restaurant.
Lots of traffic headed to/from Ishinomaki, but be wary, many smaller villages no longer exist because of the tsunami so staying along the coast will net every limited traffic.
If you get dropped off North of here along 338, you are probably screwed. The roads are extremely narrow, have almost no traffic, and konbinis are rare. Hitch at your own peril.
I waited in Tosu interchange, and looked for a right car for cc. 1 hour. Finally a family looked me, and invited me to their car.

An old man took us.
It's not a bad place as it's quite but the roads split and most cars don't go eastward along the coast. We ended up taking a short ride to Gotsu after passing many.
7-11, always good for hitchhiking. theres alot of local traffic tho
Eneos gas station in front of highway enterence. A friendly old man took us to a service station near Kitakyushu.

took around 2 hours. tried to stand at area where cars leave, however was told to stand at the storefront. it was an alright spot, but it would be uncomfortable in the summer as the sun would be facing you for the entire day, not much shade.

All the cars going to the big gas station nearby pass on that road to go back to the highway. There's space to stop but cars tend to go fast. Got picked up by two young surfers going to Fujieda. (Girl alone, with a sign to Shizuoka)

Walk along the path recommended by Google Maps, you'll need to jump a fence to get to the Rest Area. Also careful for bears! Not a lot of traffic. For Nagoya, I advise to try near Shirakawago instead where there's a massive flow of tourists in cars.
Entered the northbound service area very easily through the translucid sliding exit door (big å‡ºå£ in red) by the road. Good way to get to Nagano from Kofu city.
Very little traffic, mainly trucks. Got picked up really quick tho
Not really a good spot, the cars didn't have a lot of place to stop
got sexually harassed here

First of all it's hard to find good spots from Nobeoka in the direction on Kumamoto in my opinion.
There is just a right amount of cars passing here(1 every 10 or 20 seconds) and at least half of them go to the IC, that's why I stood here.
They don't go too fast so they have time to see you and there is a good space just behind you so that even a small truck can park (it was a small truck that took me).
I wrote "Hajimemashite Takachiho" in Japanese on my sign.
It's a free highway with traffic lights, there's a Lawson convenience store nearby, you can use the toilets and wifi.
Slightly secluded and hard for you to signal to drivers because the road forks. However most likely the best SA to be dropped at if you are heading to Saga instead coming from the East.
Good spot for cars to pull over, but not much traffic. Be careful to not wave for the bus. Only took this route to get out of miyoshi

I tried higher up on the on-ramp for 30 minutes but there wasnâ€™t room to stop. Once I moved down to the pin (entrance to the ramp) it only took like 15-20 minutes. Stand right closer to beginning so cars have time to stop.
Waited a bit for this one, about an hour. Going north towards Takashima. I waited near the exit for cars going west but the Lawson is on the opposite side of the road so not many cars.
Not very accessable but a good location to get dropped off and catch another ride. Good infrastructure, small enough to be seen from the whole parking area and enough traffic to get picked up fast.

Tried to get to Tokyo, but only got offered 3 rides to Utsunomiya. So I took the chance. Still worth because the train from Utsunomiya is cheaper then from Nikko and it's only a 30 min ride. For the mediocre traffic still many people who stopped.
We got picked up within 5 minutes, but we were lucky - it's a tiny area. There are no real alternatives though, if you're heading for Tokyo.

So admittedly, someone picked me up after about 20 minutes. It wasn't going where I wanted, but as I was giving up anyway I accepted. It's one of those depressingly tiny parking areas that have no traffic. It might look like a tempting way out of Nagano, but I really wouldn't recommend it.
A tiny service area in walking distance from Sakai station up a fairly steep hill.

Parking area near a train station.

Decided not to go there because there are some very strict sounding signs warning against crossing over to the other side of the highway - if my Japanese is not mistaken, because of dangerous animals. So although this place is relatively accessible from Gifu, unless you don't mind some explicitly illegal fence jumping, probably don't try here.
It's a bad place because the lane leading to the high way is far away from footpath. There is no chance for anypne to stop
Going Izumo->Hiroshima, I should have stuck with route 54.
The only thing this PA has is a toilet. Certainly, it doesn't have very many cars. Same goes for the next PA too.

As of September 2012, this town is almost non-existant. The ferry does not run to the island, and the museum was severely damaged. Do not hitch here expecting to find any sort of tourism. Getting dropped here without provisions could be seriously dangerous.

Morioka IC. Traffic moves much too fast. If you must try, from the side coming towards Morioka is probably better because there's actually some room on the on-ramp where someone could possibly stop, but I would not count on it.
I waited for 45 minutes. But the drivers helped me to search the next car.
Tre malfacla, principe dum la nokto. Homo kiu helpis min ne iris en tia direkto, sed elpis min per la bona koro.
At the ENEOS station. Very low traffic on a Saturday morning. Despite being close to the IC entrance, it's hard for cars to stop there and nobody goes towards Shirakawa. Possible nevertheless!
I tried to hitchike for 1 hour and 30mins with a sign and thumb. Just one person gave me a bottle of water. No one stopped to give me a ride.

free highway!
Not many cars pass by. There is Lawson which is open until 22:00 in this small town. It is a bit of a bad place to hitchhike not many people stop.
After trying to hitchhike for 2 hours, a Korean woman took me to Fukui city

There is an ok place to pullover here and decent traffic, but it was very frustrating. I tried signs saying Tokyo, mt Fuji and gotemba, but people often gave the bs hand gestures saying they where going short distance, even though all cars where going in a useful direction and a short ride would have taken me out of the middle of knowhere and back to civilisation. They don't seem to understand the concept of a partial ride. Fujiyoshida would probably be a better thing to write on your sign, from

Screw this hellhole. Had tons of visibility, tons of space, tons of traffic, yet it took 2 hours for someone to stop when I had a sign for a place literally 20 mins up the road almost everyone here would drive along. plenty of people waved and some even came over and took selfie with me, but nobody picked me up for 2 hours getting burnt in the sun. A place where the quality of the spot makes a 2 hour wait excessive. The guy who stopped was amazing and had travelled himself so kudos to him. Googl

Couldn't find a ride to the highway, I waited at that Lawson for 6 hours but most cars would go to the bypass and not the EA1 Shin Tomei highway. So I would recommend using the bus from Shizuoka station to the Service Area as recommended on that pin about 20km west.

You canâ€™t hitchhike to Yamagata on this road. Itâ€™s the city centre and all the cars use the middle and 3rd lanes to go to Yamagata, and drive fairly fast. After this point shortly the road goes underground and thereâ€™s no other spot other than inside the city. I found it impossible to hitchhike, took the bus to Yamagata for 1200 ten.
